Hakron
description: Everything You Need to Know About Agentic AI Hackathon 2026 Time:  24-Hour Hackathon (Overnight) Mode:  Offline Venue:  Ajeenkya DY Patil University, School of Management, Lohegaon, Near Airport Road, Pune Date:  January 30th – January 31st, 2026 About the Event Agentic AI Hackathon 2026 is a  24-hour offline hackathon  where students build  real AI agents  capable of thinking, planning, using tools, and completing tasks autonomously. This event introduces participants to the future of AI —  Agentic Systems  — through hands-on learning, real-world problem statements, and competitive building. Participants will design  end-to-end intelligent agents  that reason, act, and deliver results. Before the hackathon begins, participants will attend a  2-hour hands-on Agentic AI Workshop , conducted by our sponsoring partners. What to Expect 2-hour pre-hackathon Agentic AI Workshop  on agent workflows, planning, and tool calling Build AI agents that  understand tasks, break them into steps, and use APIs/tools Agent League  — India’s first live AI-vs-AI arena Top agents showcased on  AgentIndia.dev Exclusive  builder badges  for GitHub, LinkedIn, and Instagram Agent Passport  to track your journey Sign the  Wall of Future Founders Event Details Event Name:  Agentic AI Hackathon 2026 Event Mode:  Offline Team Size:  3–5 members Eligibility:  Open to all Indian undergraduate college students (any branch, any year) Cross-College Teams:  Allowed Registration Fee:  ₹699 per team Prize Pool:  ₹90,000 Platform:  Unstop (for registration and announcements) Refreshments & Goodies:  Meals, snacks, beverages, and exclusive goodies Theme Build an  AI Agent  capable of: Understanding tasks Breaking them into logical steps Using APIs / tools Producing reliable end-to-end outputs Problem statements will be released on Day 1. Competition Format Teams will build a  working AI agent prototype from scratch  within 24 hours. A fully production-ready product is  not mandatory , but a  functional prototype  is required. Submission Requirements Teams must submit: GitHub Repository  (code + tool integrations) README  with setup instructions Architecture Diagram Demo Video (2–3 mins)  showing the agent solving a real task Short Write-Up (max 400 words) : Problem Approach How the agent works Shortlisted teams will present live. Judging Criteria Planning & Reasoning Tool Use / API Integration Execution & Reliability Impact & Usefulness Demo Quality Rules & Code of Conduct Original work only No plagiarism or auto-generated full projects No harmful or unethical agents Respectful conduct mandatory Judges’ decisions are final Official Rulebook Community Link: Community Link IP Policy Teams retain  100% ownership  o

title: Anantya- Codigo 2026
description: Official Event Overview: Codigo 2026 is a competitive programming contest conducted under  Anantya , designed to evaluate participants’ problem-solving abilities, logical reasoning, and proficiency in  Data Structures and Algorithms (DSA) . The competition progresses through multiple elimination rounds, simulating real-world competitive programming and ICPC-style environments. Event Details: Event Name:  Codigo 2026 Format:  Multi-Round Competitive Programming Contest Mode:  Online and Offline Eligibility Criteria: Open to undergraduate students Inter-college participation is allowed Participants must compete in teams Each participant may register only once Team Formation: Participation is allowed in teams Team size:  3 members (mandatory) Team composition must remain unchanged throughout the competition Problem Domains: Participants will solve problems primarily focused on: Data Structures and Algorithms (DSA) Logical reasoning and problem-solving Competitive programming techniques and optimizations Competition Structure: Round 1: Qualifier Round Mode:  Online Date:  20 January 2026 This round serves as the initial qualifier to test core DSA knowledge and competitive programming fundamentals. Based on performance,  45 teams  will be shortlisted for the Semi-Final Round. Round 2: Semi-Final Round Mode:  Online Date:  22 January 2026 Duration:  2 Hours Teams will solve  5 DSA-based problems  designed to test logical depth and implementation accuracy. Based on performance, the  top 20 teams  will qualify for the Final Round. Round 3: Final Round Mode:  Offline / Online (as per platform setup) Date:  22 January 2026 Duration:  2.5 Hours The final round consists of  5 DSA-based problems  at a higher difficulty level. The  top 3 teams  based on overall performance will be declared winners of Codigo 2026. Rules and Regulations: Any form of plagiarism, cheating, or use of unfair means will result in immediate disqualification Tampering with platforms or violating contest guidelines is strictly prohibited Team composition cannot be changed after registration The decision of the organizing committee of  Anantya – Codigo 2026  shall be final and binding in all matters Result Declaration: Results will be declared after the completion of the Final Round The  Top 3 teams  will be announced as winners of  Codigo 2026  through official communication channels

Titanic - Machine Learning from Disaster
description: This is the legendary Titanic ML competition – the best, first challenge for you to dive into ML competitions and familiarize yourself with how the Kaggle platform works.

title: House Prices - Advanced Regression Techniques
description: You have some experience with R or Python and machine learning basics. This is a perfect competition for data science students who have completed an online course in machine learning and are looking to expand their skill set before trying a featured competition.

title: Spaceship Titanic
description: We highly recommendTitanic - Machine Learning from Disasterto get familiar with the basics of machine learning and Kaggle competitions.

title: LLM Classification Finetuning
description: This competition challenges you to predict which responses users will prefer in a head-to-head battle between chatbots powered by large language models (LLMs). You'll be given a dataset of conversations from theChatbot Arena, where different LLMs generate answers to user prompts. By developing a winning machine learning model, you'll help improve how chatbots interact with humans and ensure they better align with human preferences.

title: AI Mathematical Olympiad - Progress Prize 3
description: The goal of this competition is to create open-source algorithms and models that can solve olympiad-level math problems written in LaTeX format. Your participation will help to advance AI models’ mathematical reasoning skills and drive frontier knowledge.

title: Vesuvius Challenge - Surface Detection
description: Some ancient scrolls are too fragile to open, but that doesn’t mean we can’t read them. Can your model help?

title: The MedGemma Impact Challenge
description: Build human-centered AI applications with MedGemma and other open models from Google’s Health AI Developer Foundations (HAI-DEF).

title: CSIRO - Image2Biomass Prediction
description: Build models that predict pasture biomass from images, ground-truth measurements, and publicly available datasets. Farmers will use these models to determine when and how to graze their livestock.

title: Stanford RNA 3D Folding Part 2
description: If you were handed only a melody and asked to compose a full symphony, you’d need to rely on patterns, structure, and musical intuition to build the rest. In the same way, predicting Ribonucleic acid (RNA)’s 3D structure means using its sequence to determine how it folds into the shapes that define its function.

title: Santa 2025 - Christmas Tree Packing Challenge
description: How many Christmas trees can fit in a box? Help solve a classic optimization problem with a festive twist.

title: CAFA 6 Protein Function Prediction
description: Proteins are large molecules that are responsible for many activities in our cells, tissues, organs, and bodies and they also play a central role in the structure and function of cells. Proteins are composed of 20 types of smaller molecules known as amino acids, which are ordered in a long chain known as the protein amino acid sequence. Each protein has its own sequence that determines its structure and its function. You will build a model that predicts what a protein does based on its amino aci

title: PhysioNet - Digitization of ECG Images
description: You will build models to extract time series data from Electrocardiogram (ECG) images. ECGs are used to diagnose and guide treatment for heart disease. They exist as physical printouts, scanned images, photographs, or time series. Medical-grade ECG software currently works best on time series. Tools for extracting time series from ECG images can help convert billions of ECG images collected globally over decades into data for training better diagnostic models to improve clinical outcomes.

title: Deep Past Challenge - Translate Akkadian to English
description: In this competition, you will help decode the everyday business records of ancient Assyrian merchants. Using data from 8,000 cuneiform texts, your goal is to build a translation system for Old Assyrian. Thousands more like them lie unread in museum drawers around the world.

title: Predicting Student Test Scores
description: Welcome to the 2026 Kaggle Playground Series!We plan to continue in the spirit of previous playgrounds, providing interesting and approachable datasets for our community to practice their machine learning skills, and anticipate a competition each month.

title: Hull Tactical - Market Prediction
description: Your task is to predict the stock market returns as represented by the excess returns of the S&P 500 while also managing volatility constraints. Your work will test the Efficient Market Hypothesis and challenge common tenets of personal finance.

title: Recod.ai/LUC - Scientific Image Forgery Detection
description: Develop methods that can accurately detect and segment copy-move forgeries within biomedical research images.

title: Thermophysical Property: Melting Point
description: Your goal is to build ML models that predict melting point in temperature units of Kelvin for organic compounds given molecular descriptors.

title: MALLORN Astronomical Classification Challenge
description: The10-Year Legacy Survey of Space and Time (LSST)using theVera C. Rubin Observatorywill soon begin. It is expected to revolutionise time-domain astronomy, discovering100xmore astronomical transients (such as supernovae) than we’ve ever discovered.

title: MITSUI&CO. Commodity Prediction Challenge
description: In this competition, you are challenged to develop a model capable of predicting future commodity returns using historical data from London Metal Exchange (LME), Japan Exchange Group (JPX), US Stock, and Forex markets. Leveraging insights from these diverse datasets is key to building stable, long-term forecasts crucial for optimizing trading strategies and managing risk in global commodity markets.

title: Google Tunix Hack - Train a model to show its work
description: Most open-source or open-weight language models can give you an answer. But they typically don’t ‘show their work’ - the steps they went through to arrive at that conclusion in a consistent manner. Here, you’ll useTunix, Google’s new JAX-native library for LLM post-training, to train a model to show its work by laying out a reasoning trace before landing on an answer.

title: Veni Vidi Vici
description: ================================================================================== ANNOUCEMENT: Platform Registrations are now open  Register via the official platform: https://ctf-codingclub.iitdh.ac.in/ ️ Ensure your email ID and personal details match exactly across all platforms. Any mismatch will lead to disqualification . Join our official Discord server for all updates and announcements: https://discord.gg/WcGQbUXf8A Once joined, keep monitoring the #vvv channel regularly — all important updates will be posted there. Register early and stay alert. ================================================================================== PARSEC’s premier Capture The Flag (CTF) competition that tests your skills in cryptography, forensics, reverse engineering, web exploitation, OSINT and more. Designed for both seasoned hackers and curious newcomers, Veni Vidi Vici challenges participants to solve a series of progressively complex puzzles — each revealing a hidden flag and taking you one step closer to victory. Whether you compete solo or as part of a team, your problem-solving skills, analytical thinking, and technical mastery will be pushed to the limit.Further details will be provided in the discord channel Guidelines:  Participation Eligibility: Any UG/PG students from all around the world Prize Eligibility: Any undergraduate/postgraduate students across colleges in India Team Size: 1-3 members Duration: 48 hours Mode: Online Style: Jeopardy Rules : A Team ID will be allocated to the team on registration which shall be used for future references. The decision of the organizers or judges shall be treated as final and binding on all. Use the same email ID you registered with on Unstop to create your account on the CTF website. Do not attempt to overwhelm or attack the infrastructure. Any such activity, including brute-forcing flags, will result in immediate disqualification. If you discover a vulnerability in the CTF infrastructure, report it immediately to the organizing team. Do not exploit, disclose or share vulnerabilities through public platforms or any other means. Do not share flags with other teams or participants. Sharing flags will lead to disqualification. Dynamic scoring is enabled. As more teams solve a challenge, its point value decreases for everyone. Sharing flags helps your opponents and reduces your own score. Ensure all flags are submitted in the correct format: parsec{flag_text} Flags submitted in an incorrect format will not be accepted.

title: Sustain Tech Hackathon
description: SustainTech Hackathon is a software-focused innovation challenge where students build digital solutions to tackle sustainability issues within college campuses. Campuses operate like small cities, consuming large amounts of energy, water, paper, and infrastructure resources—often mismanaged due to poor visibility and outdated systems. This hackathon emphasizes practical, implementable software solutions that enhance efficiency, transparency, awareness, and long-term sustainability on campus. Hardware-based or purely theoretical ideas are not required . Eligibility: Open to students from all universities and colleges , across any discipline Team size: 1–4 members All team members must belong to the same institution A participant may be part of only one team Problem Statement: Design and develop a software-based solution to address a sustainability challenge within a college or university campus The solution should: Improve efficient use of resources Reduce waste and operational inefficiencies Enhance transparency, awareness, and accountability Support long-term environmental, economic, or social sustainability Problem Domains: Energy Management Water Management Waste Management & Cleanliness Paperless Administration Transportation & Mobility Hostel & Facility Management Student Awareness & Sustainability Engagement Any other campus-related sustainability challenge Solution Requirements: Solution must be purely software-based No hardware implementation required Acceptable formats include: Web applications, Mobile applications or Progressive Web Apps (PWA), Dashboards/portals, Data-driven or AI-based systems Solutions must be realistic, feasible, and deployable in a campus setting EVENT STRUCTURE (TWO ROUNDS) Round 1: A)Problem Statement Understanding and Solution Proposal (Online) What to Submit: A PPT covering problem understanding, sustainability gap, proposed software solution, target users & impact, and a high-level system approach. Note: No coding or working prototype required in this round. Participants are encouraged to use the provided PPT template, while adding their own creative touch. Round 1:B) Online Presentation Shortlisted teams will present their solution online  Join the official coordination group for updates & queries:  WhatsApp Group For More Details: Refer Rulebook and Explanatory Video Teams must show a wireframe of the proposed software solution   Evaluation Focus:   Clarity of problem understanding   Relevance to campus sustainability   Feasibility and practicality   Quality and clarity of wireframe and user flow Round 2: A)Prototype Development Phase Shortlisted teams will develop their software prototype  Focus areas include functionality, usability, and deployment potential Teams should prepare for offline evaluation  Date: 16 February 2026  Duration: 12-hour hackathon Round 2: B)Offline Demonstration and Evaluat

title: HackQuinox
description: All that you need to know about HackQuinox 2.0 For the second edition of HackQuinox, Fr. C. Rodrigues Institute of Technology is hosting HackQuinox 2.0, a 2-day offline hackathon designed to foster innovation, collaboration, and real-world problem solving. This event is a joint collaboration between the CSI, AIDL, and CSI-IT clubs of FCRIT. Join us for an exciting journey of creativity, technology, and collaboration as you build impactful solutions to real-world problems. Dates : 1st and 2nd February 2025 Team Size : 2–4 Members Domains : Housing Justice & Urban Belonging, FinTech & Financial Inclusion, AgriTech & Sustainability, EdTech & Skill Development, Accessibility & Assistive Technology, Open Innovation Eligibility : Open to all undergraduate students only. Note : Teams can consist of members from different colleges, years, and branches/specializations. Rounds Overview : The hackathon will be conducted in offline mode. All registered teams will participate in the Development Round on Day 1. Teams will work on ideation, development, and prototyping of their solutions. Based on jury evaluation, shortlisted teams will advance to the Final Presentation Round on Day Finalist teams will present their solutions before an expert jury panel. The top teams will be declared winners based on overall jury evaluation. Development Round (Day 1) Details: Date: 1st February 2025 Mode: Offline Location: Fr. C. Rodrigues Institute of Technology Reporting Time: 8:00 AM All teams must report on time with Aadhaar Card, College ID, and one passport-size photograph. Teams will be allotted seating upon arrival. Participants may bring personal laptops with their own internet connectivity. College Wi-Fi is permitted only on college PCs. Development must be completed by 7:00 PM. Attendance of all team members is mandatory. Breakfast, lunch, and snacks will be provided for all participants on Day 1. Final Presentation Round (Day 2) Details: Date: 2nd February 2025 Mode: Offline Location: Fr. C. Rodrigues Institute of Technology Shortlisted teams will present their solutions in front of a panel of judges. Each team will be allotted 8 minutes for presentation followed by 4 minutes of Q&A. A working prototype demonstration is mandatory. PPT is optional, but if used, teams must strictly follow the provided template. No extra time will be given beyond the allotted duration. The winners will be announced on the same day. Teams will receive constructive feedback from the judges. Fees : Registration Fee: Applicable for shortlisted teams. The exact fee amount and payment details will be communicated by the organizers. Prizes : Exciting cash prizes and exclusive goodies for the winning teams. Certificates of participation for all teams. Certificates of excellence for top-performing teams.
